question_text: $\overline{PR}$ and $\overline{SU}$ are parallel lines. Which angles are supplementary angles?
backend_description: The image shows two parallel vertical lines, labeled PR and SU, intersected by a diagonal transversal line VO. Points of intersection are marked at Q on line PR and T on line SU. Additional labeled points include S and P above the intersections, and U and R below. The transversal forms various angles at the points of intersection, including angles PQT and PQO. Together they form a straight line.
question_type: Multiple Choice Question with Single Answer
solution: First find $\angle$PQT.

Check each pair of angles.
$\angle$PQT and $\angle$STV are not supplementary angles. Their measures do not add up to 180°.
$\angle$PQT and $\angle$UTQ are not supplementary angles. Their measures do not add up to 180°.
$\angle$PQT and $\angle$RQO are not supplementary angles. Their measures do not add up to 180°.
$\angle$PQT and $\angle$PQO are supplementary angles. Their measures add up to 180°.
solution_image_tag: The image shows two vertical parallel lines: SU on the left and PR on the right. A diagonal transversal line VO intersects both at points T and Q, respectively. A blue arc highlights ∠PQT, which is formed by the intersection of lines PR and VO, opening to the left between segments QP and QT.

This image is identical to step 1 (Gr8_37_3_1_step_1) but adds a green arc to mark ∠STV, which is formed at the left intersection of transversal VO and line SU, opening to the left between segments TS and TV. The blue arc for ∠PQT remains.
This image is identical to step 1 (Gr8_37_3_1_step_1) but adds a green arc highlights ∠UTQ, formed at point T between TU and TQ. The blue arc still marks ∠PQT at point Q.
This image is identical to step 1 (Gr8_37_3_1_step_1) but adds a green arc highlights ∠RQO, the angle at Q opening to the right between QR and QO. The blue arc remains on ∠PQT.

This image is identical to step 1 (Gr8_37_3_1_step_1) but adds a green arc highlights ∠PQO. ∠PQT (blue) and ∠PQO (green) both share vertex Q. The two angles are adjacent and lie on a straight line from point P to O, forming a linear pair. Together, they are supplementary and sum to 180°.

Additional labeled points include L and I above the intersections, and N and K below. The transversal creates multiple angles at the points of intersection, including angles KJM and IJH, which are vertical angles formed by the intersection of lines OH and IK.
question_type: Multiple Choice Question with Single Answer
solution: First find $\angle$KJM.

Check each pair of angles.
$\angle$KJM and $\angle$LMO are not vertical angles. They are not formed by the same pair of intersecting lines.
$\angle$KJM and $\angle$NMO are not vertical angles. They are not formed by the same pair of intersecting lines.
$\angle$KJM and $\angle$NMJ are not vertical angles. They are not formed by the same pair of intersecting lines.
$\angle$KJM and $\angle$IJH are vertical angles. They are formed by intersecting lines $\overline{HO}$ and $\overline{IK}$ and are not adjacent.

solution: First find $\angle$LMO.

Check each pair of angles.
$\angle$LMO and $\angle$IJH are not adjacent angles. They do not have a common side.
$\angle$LMO and $\angle$KJH are not adjacent angles. They do not have a common side.
$\angle$LMO and $\angle$NMO are adjacent angles. They share the ray $\overline{MO}$.
$\angle$LMO and $\angle$NMJ are not adjacent angles. They do not have a common side.
